items.title: Exercise 1: Stakeholder Engagement Plan (Doc A)
items.text:
Doc A — Project Alpha: Stakeholder Engagement Plan

Objective: To ensure the successful launch of the new client portal, which was approved by the board last month. We have identified several key stakeholders whom we must manage closely.

Key Stakeholders:
1. Finance Director (High Power, High Interest): Mr. Davies, whose approval is required for all project expenses, will receive weekly updates.
2. Client Success Team (Low Power, High Interest): These are the users who will use the portal daily. We will consult them during the testing phase.
3. External Vendors (Low Power, Low Interest): They will be kept informed via the monthly newsletter.

Strategy: We will leverage our existing relationship with the IT department to streamline the launch. It is essential that we reach out to the Finance Director before Friday to confirm the budget allocation.

questions.question: Which stakeholder group should be 'managed closely' according to the plan?
questions.explanation: Doc A classifies the Finance Director as 'High Power, High Interest', meaning he must be managed closely.

questions.question: What strategy is mentioned to help 'streamline' the launch?
options: Leveraging the existing relationship with the IT department.
Reaching out to the board members.
questions.explanation: Doc A states: 'We will leverage our existing relationship with the IT department to streamline the launch.'

items.prompt: Exercise 2: Stakeholder Matrix. How should you handle a stakeholder with 'High Power' but 'Low Interest'?
items.explanation: According to the stakeholder matrix, High Power/Low Interest individuals should be 'kept satisfied'.

items.prompt: Exercise 3: Networking Vocabulary. What is an 'Elevator Pitch'?
options: A long speech about your life history.
A concise, persuasive summary of who you are and what you do.
A formal complaint about the office lift.
items.explanation: An elevator pitch is a short, persuasive summary of yourself and your role.

items.prompt: Exercise 4: Professional Chunks. Complete the sentence: 'I am ___ to discuss a potential ___ that would be ___ for both of us.'
items.explanation: 'Reaching out' for 'collaboration' that is 'mutually beneficial' is standard professional phrasing.

items.prompt: Exercise 5: Defining Relative Clauses. Combine these two sentences into one using 'who' or 'that' (no commas): 'The person is the project lead. The person sent the email.'
items.modelAnswer: The person who sent the email is the project lead.

items.prompt: Exercise 6: Non-Defining Relative Clauses. Combine these two sentences into one using 'which' and commas: 'The new portal is very fast. The new portal cost £50,000.'
items.modelAnswer: The new portal, which cost £50,000, is very fast.

items.prompt: Exercise 7: Extracting Action Points. Based on Doc A, list the specific outreach task and its deadline.
items.modelAnswer: Action: Reach out to the Finance Director. Deadline: Before Friday.

items.prompt: Exercise 8: Courtesy Modals. Which is the most professional way to 'reach out' to a senior stakeholder for a consultation?
options: I am reaching out to request a brief consultation on the portal launch. Would you be able to provide your feedback by Wednesday?
Why haven't you responded to my stakeholder map?
Send me your thoughts on the project.
items.explanation: This option uses 'reaching out', 'request', and a polite modal ('Would you be able to...').

items.prompt: Exercise 9: Networking Follow-up. Write a 50-word follow-up email to Mr. Davies (from Doc A) after a brief meeting at a conference. Mention 'mutual benefit'.
items.modelAnswer: Dear Mr. Davies, it was a pleasure meeting you at the conference today. I’m reaching out to follow up on our discussion regarding the new portal. I believe this collaboration will be mutually beneficial for both Finance and Operations. I’ll send the full proposal shortly. Best regards, [Your Name]

items.prompt: Exercise 10: Operational Logic. If a stakeholder has 'Low Power' but 'High Interest', what is the best strategy?
items.explanation: Low Power/High Interest stakeholders should be 'kept informed'.

items.prompt: Exercise 11: Elevator Pitch Prep. Prepare a script for a 30-second elevator pitch. Include your role, a key project you are 'leveraging', and your goal for a 'mutually beneficial' outcome.
items.modelAnswer: [Audio Upload Required] Rubric: Concise, Persuasive, Use of key networking terms.

items.prompt: Exercise 12: Oral Outreach. Record a 60-second audio reaching out to the IT department to 'coordinate logistics' for the portal launch. Use a relative clause.
items.modelAnswer: [Audio Upload Required] Checklist: Relative clause accuracy, Politeness, Clear request.

items.prompt: Exercise 13: Stakeholder Map & Plan (Portfolio). Write a 200-word engagement plan for a new 'Office Sustainability' project. Use at least two relative clauses and the term 'stakeholder mapping'.
items.modelAnswer:
Our first step for the Office Sustainability project is to perform stakeholder mapping. We have identified the Facilities Manager, who is responsible for building maintenance, as a high-power stakeholder. The green committee, which was formed last month, has high interest but low power. 

We will reach out to the Facilities Manager to ensure we have his buy-in before we install the new recycling bins. The committee, whose feedback is vital for engagement, will be kept informed via weekly meetings. Our goal is to leverage these relationships to ensure a mutually beneficial outcome for the whole company. We will follow up with a full report by Friday.

items.prompt: Exercise 14: Networking Log. Complete a log for 3 contacts. Include: Name | Company | Interest Level | Follow-up Action.
items.modelAnswer: 1. Mr. Davies | Finance Ltd | High | Email proposal. 2. Sarah | IT Solutions | Medium | Follow up on LinkedIn. 3. John | Green Co | High | Schedule 15-min call.

items.prompt: Exercise 15: Weekly Mini-test. 1) Define 'Stakeholder'. 2) What does it mean to 'leverage' a connection? 3) Add commas if needed: 'The report which I wrote is long.' 4) Complete: 'I am reaching ___ to discuss...'
items.modelAnswer: 1) A person or group with an interest in a project. 2) To use a connection to maximum advantage. 3) The report, which I wrote, is long (if non-defining) or No commas (if defining). 4) out.

items.title: Exercise 16: Networking in London’s Financial District
items.text: Attending a **networking** event in the City of London requires a blend of professional confidence and social grace. Last night’s 'Tech-Finance Mixer' provided a perfect opportunity to **reach out** to potential collaborators. The key to success was not the number of business cards collected, but the quality of the **rapport** established. Many attendees focused on their **Elevator Pitch**, ensuring they could concisely explain their value proposition. However, the most successful participants were those who practiced **reciprocity**, offering insights or introductions before asking for anything in return. After the event, the standard protocol is to **follow up** via LinkedIn within 24 hours to **reiterate** the points discussed and propose a brief 'coffee chat' to explore **mutually beneficial** opportunities.

questions.question: What was more important than collecting business cards at the event?
questions.explanation: The text states: 'The key to success was not the number of business cards... but the quality of the rapport established.'

questions.question: According to the text, what should you do before asking for a favour?
questions.explanation: The text mentions that successful participants practiced reciprocity by offering value before asking for something.

items.title: Exercise 17: Highlighted Vocabulary
items.prompt: Match the terms from the reading with their definitions.

pairs.definition: A harmonious relationship based on understanding.
To say something again for emphasis or clarity.
A person who works with others on a project.

items.prompt: Exercise 18: Identifying the Stakeholder. A local community group is worried about the noise from a new construction project. They have little power to stop it but are very concerned. Where do they fit in the Mendelow Matrix?
items.explanation: They have High Interest but Low Power, so they should be 'Kept Informed'.

items.prompt: Exercise 19: Relative Clauses. Choose the correct pronoun: 'The office ___ we hold our networking events is currently being renovated.'
Exercise 20: Relative Clauses. Choose the correct pronoun: 'This is Sarah, ___ department handles all external stakeholder communications.'
items.explanation: 'Whose' is used to show possession (Sarah's department).

items.prompt: Exercise 21: Formal Grammar. Select the most formal option: 'The manager ___ I spoke was very helpful.'
items.explanation: 'With whom' is the most formal way to refer to a person as the object of a preposition.

items.prompt: Exercise 22: Non-defining Clauses. Which sentence is punctuated correctly?
options: The Mendelow Matrix which helps us map stakeholders is a vital tool.
The Mendelow Matrix, which helps us map stakeholders, is a vital tool.
The Mendelow Matrix which, helps us map stakeholders, is a vital tool.
The Mendelow Matrix, which helps us map stakeholders is a vital tool.
items.explanation: Non-defining clauses require commas before and after the clause.

items.prompt: Exercise 23: Defining Clauses (Omission). In which sentence can you omit the relative pronoun?
options: The person who is leading the meeting is late.
The report that contains the data is on your desk.
The contact whom I met at the event was very knowledgeable.
The company which won the contract is based in Manchester.
items.explanation: You can omit 'whom' (or 'that') when it is the object of the clause: 'The contact [whom] I met...'

items.prompt: Exercise 24: Phrasal Verbs. To 'touch base' with someone means:
options: To play a game of baseball
To contact someone briefly to stay updated
items.explanation: 'Touch base' is a common idiom for making quick contact.

items.title: Exercise 25: Oral Recording Task 1 - Networking Intro
items.prompt: You are at a professional networking mixer. Record your 'Elevator Pitch' (approx. 45 seconds). Mention: 1) Your administrative role, 2) A project you are currently 'leveraging', and 3) A proposal for a 'mutually beneficial' follow-up.
items.modelAnswer: Hello, I am the Senior Administrator for Project Alpha. Currently, I am leveraging our new client portal to streamline operations. I'd love to discuss how our data models might be mutually beneficial for your team. Would you be open to touching base next week for a brief coffee chat?

items.title: Exercise 26: Listening Glossary
items.prompt: Preview these terms before listening to the dialogue.

terms.definition: Feeling resentment at having been unfairly treated.
To make someone less angry or hostile.
A personal reason for involvement in an undertaking.
Conflict or animosity caused by a clash of wills.

items.title: Exercise 27: Stakeholder Conflict Resolution
items.prompt: Listen to the dialogue between an Admin Manager and a Project Lead regarding a difficult stakeholder.

questions.question: What is the main concern of the 'aggrieved' stakeholder?
questions.explanation: The dialogue reveals the stakeholder feels ignored and wants more transparency.

questions.question: What strategy does the manager suggest to 'placate' the stakeholder?
options: Offering a formal apology and a seat on the board
Increasing their frequency of updates and inviting them to a steering meeting
questions.explanation: The manager suggests moving them to the 'Keep Satisfied' or 'Key Player' group with more involvement.

items.title: Exercise 28: Networking at a Conference
items.prompt: Listen to James delivering his elevator pitch to a potential collaborator.

questions.question: What does James 'bring to the table'?
options: 10 years of experience in logistics automation
questions.explanation: James mentions his decade of experience in automation as his value proposition.

questions.question: How does the other person respond to James's pitch?
options: They suggest James 'touches base' next week after reviewing his LinkedIn
They offer him a job immediately
questions.explanation: The contact suggests following up to discuss things further.

items.title: Exercise 29: Dictation
items.prompt: Listen and type the sentence exactly as you hear it.
items.answer: We must leverage our existing rapport with the key players to ensure they buy into the new stakeholder engagement strategy.
items.explanation: Focus on the spelling of 'leverage', 'rapport', and the phrasal verb 'buy into'.

items.title: Exercise 30: Gap-fill - Networking Protocol
items.prompt: Listen and fill in the missing professional terms.
items.text: When you attend an event, you should first try to establish **{rapport}** before delivering your **{elevator pitch}**. Remember that professional networking is based on **{reciprocity}**, so always look for ways to offer value. Don't forget to **{follow up}** within twenty-four hours to **{reiterate}** your interest.
items.explanation: These terms are standard in professional networking etiquette.

items.title: Exercise 31: Global Stakeholder Standards (Doc C)
items.text:
Doc C — White Paper: The Future of Global Stakeholder Engagement

Effective engagement is no longer just about communication; it is about **reciprocity**. In global markets, administrators must navigate various 'power dynamics' that aren't always visible on a standard matrix. We have identified that 'Key Players' often include local community leaders whose **buy-in** is essential for legal compliance. Furthermore, the use of **non-defining** reporting structures can lead to **friction** if not managed with transparency. To **placate** aggrieved parties, we recommend a policy of 'active listening' combined with regular, high-level **rapport-building** sessions. Those **whom** we designate as 'Key Players' will now receive a direct line to the project steering committee.

### Key Definitions
1. **Reciprocity**: The mutual exchange of value.
2. **Friction**: Conflict or resistance within a process.
3. **Placate**: To calm or satisfy an interested party.

questions.question: What is recommended to 'placate' aggrieved parties?
questions.explanation: Doc C recommends 'active listening' and 'rapport-building sessions' to placate aggrieved parties.

questions.question: Who is included in the 'Key Players' category for legal compliance?
questions.explanation: The text states that 'Key Players' often include local community leaders whose buy-in is essential.

questions.question: What can lead to 'friction' if not managed with transparency?
questions.explanation: Doc C mentions that 'non-defining reporting structures can lead to friction if not managed with transparency'.

items.prompt: Exercise 32: Relative Clauses (Reduced). Choose the correctly reduced clause: 'The stakeholders who were invited to the meeting did not attend.'
options: The stakeholders invited to the meeting did not attend.
The stakeholders inviting to the meeting did not attend.
The stakeholders invite to the meeting did not attend.
The stakeholders were invited to the meeting did not attend.
items.explanation: In passive relative clauses, we can omit 'who were' and use the past participle.

items.prompt: Exercise 33: Phrasal Verbs. I'll ___ you ___ on the latest changes to the project plan.
items.explanation: 'To keep someone in the loop' means to keep them informed.

items.prompt: Exercise 34: Business Idioms. 'What do you bring to the table?' means:
options: What skills or benefits can you offer?
items.explanation: 'Bring to the table' refers to contribution of value.

items.prompt: Exercise 35: Stakeholder Types. A supplier who provides a critical component for your product but has many other customers has:
items.explanation: Because the component is critical, they have High Power (they could stop production), but because you are just one of many customers, their interest in your specific project might be Low.

items.prompt: Exercise 36: Sentence Transformation. Rewrite using 'whose': 'That is the manager. Her department won the award.'
items.modelAnswer: That is the manager whose department won the award.

items.prompt: Exercise 37: Sentence Transformation. Rewrite using a non-defining relative clause: 'The Mendelow Matrix is a useful tool. It was created in 1991.'
items.modelAnswer: The Mendelow Matrix, which was created in 1991, is a useful tool.

items.prompt: Exercise 38: Professional Phrasing. Complete the email: 'Dear Maria, it was great to meet you. I am ___ ___ to see if we could ___ ___ next week to discuss our collaboration.'
Exercise 39: Relative Adverbs. '2023 was the year ___ we launched our first stakeholder engagement initiative.'

items.title: Exercise 40: Oral Recording Task 2 - Stakeholder Briefing
items.prompt: You need to 'reach out' to a 'High Power, Low Interest' stakeholder who is blocking a budget increase. Record a 60-second briefing to 'placate' them. Explain how the budget will 'leverage' new technology to provide a 'short-term win' for their specific department.
items.modelAnswer: Good morning. I am reaching out to discuss the upcoming budget review. I understand your concerns, but this investment will leverage automation to eliminate the current bottleneck in your department's reporting. This will provide a significant short-term win by reducing manual entry by 40%. I'd like to keep you in the loop with bi-weekly updates.

items.prompt: Exercise 41: Defining vs Non-Defining. Explain the difference in meaning: A) 'The employees who received the bonus were happy.' B) 'The employees, who received the bonus, were happy.'
items.modelAnswer: A) Only the specific employees who got the bonus were happy. B) All the employees (in the group) received the bonus and were happy.

items.prompt: Exercise 42: Vocabulary usage. Write a sentence using the word 'reciprocity' in a business context.
items.modelAnswer: The partnership was built on reciprocity, with both firms sharing their research data.

items.prompt: Exercise 43: Reduced Relative Clause. Reduce this sentence: 'The documents which were sent by the director are confidential.'
items.modelAnswer: The documents sent by the director are confidential.

items.prompt: Exercise 44: Elevator Pitch Logic. Why is it important to keep an elevator pitch under 60 seconds?
items.modelAnswer: To respect the other person's time and ensure the summary remains concise and memorable.

items.title: Exercise 45: Weekly Review - Stakeholders & Networking
items.prompt: Synthesize this week's learning: 1) Categorise a stakeholder with High Power and High Interest using the Mendelow Matrix. 2) Write a sentence using a non-defining relative clause and the word 'rapport'. 3) Explain the concept of 'reciprocity' in a networking context.
items.modelAnswer: 1) A stakeholder with High Power and High Interest is a 'Key Player' who must be managed closely. 2) Mr. Henderson, with whom I have built an excellent rapport, has agreed to the proposal. 3) Reciprocity in networking means offering value, insights, or help to others before expecting a favour in return, creating a mutually beneficial relationship.
